Although some larger departments have employed welfare officers/counsellors, this is not a viable or cost efficient and effective option for an agency the size of the Department of the House of Representatives. Moreover, staff often doubt the confidentiality of the services and the welfare officer/counsellor can have difficulty in reconciling his or her management advising role. The Employee Assistance Service was seen as providing effective, cost efficient, responsive and minimum intervention services to staff for work and family related problems. The service also reinforces one of our departmental values that the staff of the department are its most valuable asset. In October 1993 a review was completed of the employee assistance program using the following evaluation criteria agreed by the departmental occupational health and safety committee: usage rates of the service by staff and eligible relatives; feedback from staff and supervisors and unions and their expectations; cost benefit analysis of the current premium structure against a fee for service arrangement, and the views and practices of other agencies, particularly the other parliamentary departments. The parties wish to set down the terms of the agreement. NOW IT IS HEREBY AGREED as follows: 1. This Agreement shall commence on the first day of August 1990 and end on the thirty-first day of July 1991. 2. This Agreement may be terminated at any time by either party giving ninety (90) days written notice to the other ("the notice period"). On the day of expiry of the notice period, this agreement is thereby tenninated. Upon such tennination the fee paid by the client shall be calculated pro rata to the nearest month and any balance shall be refunded to the client. This agreement may be extended by a written agreement of the parties. 3. EAS shall provide the following services, as required: (a) continued consultancy regarding the Program, including the overall design, development, management and implementation of the program. (b) individual counselling and case management including: (i) cnunselling of the employees and family members until an appropriate referral to a helping agency can be made; (ii) assessment counselling to detennine type of referral necessary; (iii) referral to an appropriate facility or helping agency where appropriate; (iv) short-term counselling of employees (and family members where involved) where a referral is not appropriate; (v) monitoring the employees' progress to ensure that they are receiving assistance/treatment that most effectively meets their needs. (vi) trauma emergency counselling for additional fee per clause 9(v). (c) liaison between the client and all counselling and helping agencies that serve the client's employees and their families in matters related to the Program; (d) assistance with continuous and ongoing inservice training of the client management and supervisory staff as required by the client. Additional fees will be charged at a per diem rate for all training; (e) assistance in providing information about the Program to the client's employees through pamphlets, posters and other appropriate means; (f) ongoing monitoring and reporting on the EAS counselling service, sufficient to enable the client to gauge its effectiveness; and (g) ongoing formal recommendations for the upgrading and improvement of the Program, including the development of an annual report on program results. 4. The client shall furnish announcement brochures, posters and information pamphlets as required by the Program. All such material mentioning EAS must receive the approval of the EAS manager prior to distribution or display. 5. All records of the employees (and family members where involved) maintained by EAS in conjunction with the Program shall be confidential. Employees' records may only be released to the employee upon written request by the employee, and not to any other person, except upon court order. 6. The client has designated. . . . . . as Coordinator of the Program. The Coordinator shall serve as a liaison between EAS and management. 7. Except in emergency, employee services under the Program will be limited to problem assessment, short term counselling and referral. (No additional or ongoing treatment services will be authorised by EAS without consultation and consent of the employee.) 8. EAS agrees and acknowledges that it is acting as an independent contractor. Secretary Department of the Senate) Harry Evans ("the client") in the ) presence of: ) John Vander Wyk -ATTACHMENT B 4 August 1994 Ms Rachael Clark Durham Smith and Associates Torrens Court 15 Torrens Street ALSO SENT TO: Employee Assistance Service ACT Ltd Cameron& Associates Industrial Program Service Dear Rachael Proposal-Employee Assistance Program The Department of the Senate has operated an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) since August 1990. In order to ensure the best service for its staff, the department is seeking quotes from suitably qualified and experienced organisations for the continued provision of this program. The department invites you to submit a proposal by 22 August 1994. The services the department would like included in an EAP are: comprehensive counselling services; training and briefing sessions; trauma debriefings; and comprehensive, confidential feedback and reports for senior management. Your proposal should include: an outline of your company's profile; three client referees from government departments; a description of the services your company would provide; the costing basis of those services; and the reporting and evaluation strategies to give comprehensive, confidential feedback to the department. For your information I am enclosing a copy of the department's corporate plan. Please phone me if you need any further information. My telephone number is 277 3156 and the fax number is 277 5766. AND: The Department Of The Senate, Parliament House, Canberra ACT (the department) 1. PURPOSE The purpose of this Agreement is for IPS to provide certain employee assistance services to the department. These services will be made available from the IPS Office referred to in Item1 or any other IPS office which IPS in its sole discretion shall nominate to provide the service or by the nominee of IPS referred to in Item2 of Schedule to those employees of the department referred to in Item3 of the Schedule ("the employees") and to their immediate families (collectively referred to as the "clients"). The terms of this Agreement shall be construed to foster that purpose to the maximum extent possible. 2. DURATION 2.1 This Agreement shall be deemed to have commenced on the date referred to in Item4 of the Schedule and ends on the date referred to in Item5 of the Schedule. 2.2 Either party may terminate this Agreement at any time upon giving ninety (90) days' written notice to the other party of his intention to do so the expiration of this period this Agreement shall be determined accordingly. In the event of determination the Base Fee paid by the department to IPS which is referred to in Item6 of the Schedule shall be pro-rated to the nearest month and the balance refunded to the department. 2.3 This Agreement may be renewed or extended by written agreement of the parties. Such renewal or extension shall, unless the parties otherwise agree, be in the same form and subject to the same terms as set out in this Agreement save for this Clause 2.3. 3. PROGRAM IDENTIFICATION The services provided pursuant to this Agreement shall be furnished to clients as part of the department's Employee Assistance Program (the "program"). The program's title shall be identified clearly and conspicuously in all material distributed to employees. The department shall identify IPS to its management and supervisors and to the employees upon enquiry and both parties shall emphasise that the program is that of the department. 4. IPS SERVICES IPS shall provide the following services, as required: Psychological (a) individual counselling and case management of clients including: (i) short-term counselling where a referral is not appropriate; (ii) assessment counselling to determine if a referral to a suitable facility or helping agency is necessary; (iii) referral to a suitable facility or helping agency where appropriate; and (iv) monitoring individual client's progress to ensure that the client is receiving the assistance or treatment that most effectively meets his or her needs whilst being directly serviced by IPS. (b) liaison between the department and all suitable facilities and helping agencies that serve the clients in matters related to the program; (c) authorized on-site trauma counselling and/or critical incident debriefing. Consultative (d) continuing consultation regarding the program, including the overall design, development, management and implementation of the program; (e) assistance in providing information to the department about the program to the employees or clients (as the case may be) through pamphlets, posters and other appropriate means; (f) ongoing monitoring and reporting on the IPS counselling service, sufficient to enable the department to gauge its effectiveness; (g) ongoing formal recommendation for the upgrading and improvement of the program, including the development of an annual report of program results; (h) continuous and ongoing in-service training of the department's management, supervisory staff and employees. 5. FEES 5.1 In consideration of the services provided pursuant to this Agreement the department shall pay the fees more particularly set forth hereunder: (a) a Base Fee equal to the amount referred to in Item6 of the Schedule for the services referred to in Clause 4(a), (b), (e), (f) and (g); (b) a Daily Fee equal to the amount referred to in Item7 of the Schedule for the services referred to in Clause 4(h); (c) a Daily Fee equal to the amount referred to in Item8 of the Schedule for the services referred to in Clause 4(c); . (d) a Daily Fee equal to the amount referred to in Item9 of the Schedule for the services referred to in Clause 4(d). 5.2 The Base Fee referred to in Clause 5.1(a) shall be paid upon execution of this Agreement or as soon thereafter as mutually agreed upon between the parties and in the event that this Agreement is extended or renewed in accordance with Clause 2.3 hereof a pro-rata sum in accordance with the base fee shall be paid annually to IPS. 5.3 The Daily Fee is for a standard work day. The Daily Fee may be pro-rated in the event that IPS provides services of less or more than one (1) day. 5.4 The department shall reimburse IPS all transportation costs and other travelling costs incurred in the case of the services referred to in Clauses 4(c), (d) and (h) in connection with the said services if the services are to be provided at a location which is more than 50 kilometres from the relevant IPS office referred to in Item1 of the Schedule. Travelling time to and from the site where services are to be provided is to be taken into account in calculating the hours worked in excess of the hours applicable for the Daily Rate. Any additional hours will be charged to the department in accordance with Clause 5.3. An overnight stay will incur the cost as specified in Item 10 of the Schedule. 5.5 If a confirmed training course is cancelled within fourteen (14) days before the agreed date the charge will be fifty (50) percent of the quoted daily rate. If a confirmed training course is cancelled within forty-eight (48) hours before the agreed date the charge will be one hundred (100) percent of the quoted per diem rate. 6. MATERIALS The department shall furnish at their expense announcements, brochures, posters and information pamphlets as required to achieve the purpose of the program. All such material mentioning IPS must receive the approval of the Managing Director of IPS prior to its publication. 7. CONFIDENTIALITYIRELEASE 7.1 All counselling records maintained in conjunction with the program shall be confidential. Clients' records shall not be released to any third party except with the client's written authorisation or pursuant to a court order. 7.2 IPS will not divulge to any third party any confidential infonnation relating to the department except with the department's express written authorisation or pursuant to a court order. 8. COORDINATOR The department will nominate and appoint its own program coordinator as specified in Item 11 of the Schedule who shall serve as a liaison officer for the program in its dealings with IPS and the department's management. 9. COMPLIANCE WITH LAW The parties, their employees and agents shall comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws and rules and strictly observe all applicable records' retention and confidentiality requirements. 10. INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR IPS agrees that it is acting as an independent contractor. IPS and its employees and agents shall not act in any way which would give the impression that it has the power or authority to bind the department in any respect whatsoever. 11. RESTRAINT OF TRADE 11.1 The department hereby agrees and undertakes that it shall not without the prior written consent of IPS during the tenn of this Agreement or within a period of three (3) months of the expiration of earlier tennination hereof: (a) either alone or jointly or as a shareholder in a corporation establish, conduct, promote or participate in any business competitive with the kind conducted by IPS; (b) except as provided in this Agreement use the name "Industrial Program Service" or "IPS" or any colourable imitation of those names in connection with counselling services; (c) divulge to any person, finn or corporation or make use of or exploit any confidential infonnation relating to IPS's business including without limitation infonnation relating to customers, sales, prices, transactions, business methods, trade secrets or know-how; or (d) induce or attempt to induce any employee of IPS to leave this employment or enter into any employment with the department or any other person, finn or corporation. 11.2 The parties hereby acknowledge that the restrictions set out in this clause are: (a) reasonable having regard to the nature of this Agreement; and (b) necessary to protect the legitimate commercial interests of IPS. 12. SEVERABILITY If any provision of this Agreement is held invalid, unenforceable or illegal for any reason, this Agreement shall remain otherwise in full force apart from such provision which shall be deemed deleted. 13. ASSIGNMENT This Agreement is personal in nature and cannot be assigned, subcontracted or transferred by IPS without the prior written consent of the department. This Agreement shall bind the successors and pennitted assigns of each party. 14. WAIVER Failure of either party to require strict perfonnance by the other of any provision of the Agreement shall not affect its rights with respect to continued or subsequent breaches. 15. NOTICES Any notice required by this Agreement shall be in writing delivered personally, by facsimile or by registered mail to the last known address of the party. 16. ENTIRE AGREEMENT This Agreement supersedes any prior oral or written agreements between the parties concerning the program and constitutes the entire understanding between them. This Agreement shall not be changed, modified or varied except by written agreement of the parties. 17. GOVERNING LAW This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws applicable in the Australian Capital Territory and any dispute arising hereunder shall be determined by Courts of competent jurisdiction in the said Territory. Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2047 Wednesday, 21 June 1995 PAY-ROLL TAX) BILL 1995 Consideration resumed from 2 March. Second Reading That the bill be now read a second time. From 1971 to 1 August 1987, payroll tax on wages relating to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) were collected by the Commonwealth under the terms of the Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Act 1971. When the ACT self-government commenced, legislation was not put in place to make these Commonwealth authorities liable for ACT payroll tax. This bill will rectify this situation, and will make those Commonwealth authorities operating in the ACT liable to pay ACT payroll tax in the same way that they are liable to pay state and Northern Territory payroll tax. The bill applies only to those Commonwealth authorities which, immediately before the commencement of the ACT payroll tax regime, were registered as employers, or had an application for registration pending, under the payroll tax regime of the Commonwealth or of a state or territory. It will have no application to other Commonwealth authorities. Exempting provisions which would otherwise operate to exclude liability to ACT payroll tax are made inapplicable to those Commonwealth authorities. Those Commonwealth authorities that have paid ACT payroll tax before royal assent to the bill cannot recover the payments. This legislation will ensure consistency of treatment of Commonwealth authorities between the states and territories. I commend the bill to the House. delegation from Botswana are present in the gallery. On behalf of the Committee, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors. Honourable members-Hear, hear! speaker: Mr Andrews (Menzies) (10.02 A.m.)
theText: As the Assistant Treasurer ( Mr Gear) has pointedMC 2048 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 as employers under state, territory or Commonwealth payroll tax acts prior to 1 August 1987. The bill provides that such authorities are subject to the ACT Payroll Tax Act which came into effect on 1 August 1987, even though their establishing acts may confer a general exemption against state or territory taxation. It provides that, where regulations made pursuant to the act establishing the authority have the effect of making it subject to payroll tax of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory, it is subject to the ACT Payroll Tax Act 1987, Subject to one qualification where we seek further clarification, the coalition is not opposed to the bill. The ACT Payroll Tax Act commenced operation on 1 August 1987 and the bill is designed to make it clear that it applies to Commonwealth authorities as defined in the legislation. As the Assistant Treasurer pointed out, apparently some Commonwealth authorities operating in the ACT paid payroll tax to the Australian Capital Territory government assuming that its payroll tax legislation applied to them, even though they might have been entitled to a general exemption on state or territory tax. The effect of the bill is to preclude them from recovering these moneys. Clause6 of the bill provides: A Commonwealth authority that has paid tax payable under the Payroll Tax Act 1987 of the Australian Capital Territory cannot recover those payments if they were made before the commencement of this Act. The aim of clause 6 is to protect previous collections of payroll tax by the ACT government and avoid the adverse impact that refunds would have on ACT revenues. The bill is necessary to implement the power of the ACT government to levy payroll tax on these Commonwealth authorities. The bill affects only government authorities and I am informed that no private company would be adversely affected by this legislation. The adverse impact of the revenues on the ACT government, if it had to repay the payroll tax to certain authorities, could be considerable, especially as this is a situation which the current government of the ACT has inherited from its predecessor. If tax were refunded, the ACT would lose, Commonwealth authorities would gain, and no doubt a claim for the reimbursement would in tum be made by the ACT on the Commonwealth. Our query with one aspect of this legislation is with the use of the words 'tax payable' in clause 6 of the bill. It may be argued that-and it has been suggested to us-although the authorities paid tax, it was not tax payable by operation of law prior to the commencement of this bill. Therefore, a legal question arises as to whether a reference in this bill to tax payable has the effect, which is intended, of precluding the recovery of moneys if it was not tax payable under an authorised legislative instrument prior to the commencement of this bill. We are not going to stand in the way---even if we could-of the passage of this bill through the House. However, I have raised the matter with the Assistant Treasurer. I expect that it is not a matter to which he can give an immediate answer at this stage. If it cannot be adequately answered, we will seek to ask the Senate standing committee on legal and constitutional affairs to look at those particular words and that particular clause. We share the concern of the government that the bill, which purports that the money should not be recoverable, will be in fact a binding legislative instrument in the sense that it will not be challenged in the courts in any way and that the spirit of what the government intends is carried into operation. Except for the qualification that I have alluded to, the coalition does not oppose. this piece of legislation. Commonwealth Authorities (Australian Capital Territory Pay-roll Tax) Bill 1995. speaker: Mr Langmore (Fraser) (10.07 A.m.)
theText: I am glad that the opposition supports theWednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2049 its revenue base. It makes sense that the Commonwealth, as well as the private sector, should pay these kinds of taxes. In fact, the private sector sometimes complains that Commonwealth instrumentalities are not covered by tax provisions but this legislation will ensure that. The bill is entirely non-controversial and does not deserve debate for more than a moment or two. I would like to use the opportunity to talk briefly about payroll tax in total. Payroll tax is really quite a perverse tax at a time when we have high unemployment. It is a tax on employment. Payroll tax is a discouragement to employment at a time when one of the government's highest priorities, and, I do not doubt, one of the opposition's highest priorities, is to increase employment. We should be aiming in every way possible to reduce or even eliminate payroll tax. Of course, it is a state and territory tax, as is now quite clear from this legislation, so it is not something over which the Commonwealth has direct control. However, the Commonwealth could create conditions under which it was possible for the states and territories to reduce or eliminate payroll tax if other revenue sources were available. It is very speculative to talk in these terms, but it is important to speculate because we have to try to find ways of consistently and comprehensively creating the conditions in which growth of employment could be maximised. The elimination of payroll tax would be a very significant contribution· to that goal. In order to eliminate payroll tax, we would have to find some other comparable source of revenue to replace it. It is a major source of revenue for the states and territories but there are other such sources available. If payroll tax were eliminated then corporate tax collections would rise and they would go to the Commonwealth. That would give the Commonwealth the capacity to increase direct payments to the states, which would, in part, offset the consequences of abolishing payroll tax. I understand that that might offset about a third of the loss of revenue but it would still leave about two-thirds to be found. One way in which that could be done and which has a lot of appeal to me is the idea of the introduction of some kind of greenhouse gas emission tax. That is a complex, even controversial, proposal because it involves issues relating to the incidence of such a tax which have distributional consequences. But if we want to adopt the general principle of taxing 'bads' and reducing taxes on 'goods' it makes sense to try to tax greenhouse gas emissions, to discourage those emissions and their polluting effects, whilst reducing tax on employment, which we want to encourage. SoI think there is a strong case for a more detailed exploration of the possibility of some kind of greenhouse gas emission tax. It may well not be a tax that Australia should do alone. It could well be done in conjunction with other industrialised countries and with developing countries as well. That is on the agenda of the European Community, and it may well be on the agenda of other countries as well in due course. I do not think it is an idea that will disappear. It is one that will continue to be explored because there is so much concern about greenhouse gas emissions and that concern is certainly growing. So this possibility is one that we could well explore rather more thoroughly than happened at the beginning of this year. It is certainly one that I would like to see encouraged. To conclude, I think it is very important that we absolutely minimise payroll tax. While it is right, of course, to apply it to the public sector as well as the private sector, we should be aiming to reduce it so that employment growth is encouraged. speakers, the member for Menzies( Mr Andrews) and the member for Fraser( Mr Langmore), for their contribution. Community Affairs Committee Report Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Mr Allan Morris: That the House take note of the paper. aspects of youth homelessness. At the outset, I would like to pay tribute to those members of the committee who hung in during the length of this inquiry. It was not easy but I thank them for seeing this report through to the end. I would also like to pay my tribute to Bjame Nordin and Peta Fitzgibbon for their tireless work during the inquiry and also for their help and guidance so freely offered to committee members. The sheer size of this report would hopefully suggest to those who see it that the committee has come up with a comprehensive and definitive statement regarding this vital issue which now impacts on so many families throughout Australia. The committee's terms of reference are worth repeating: To inquire into and report to the Parliament on the provision of assistance for homeless youth requiring income support, with particular reference to: 1. the availability of family support and welfare services (including mediation services), their role and effectiveness in reducing homelessness and in resolving differences before young people leave home; 2. the integration of income support provisions for homeless young people with services that assist with family reunion, transition to stable independent living, and opportunities for education, training and employment; and 3. the appropriateness of income support arrangements for homeless young people, noting the need to not create undue incentives to leave home or school. The issue of youth homelessness is a very emotive one. Stories abound across the length and breadth of this country which highlight the inadequacies of the system which is supposed to strengthen rather than weaken the roles of families in nurturing and supporting their children. The roles of state and federal governments and their various departments have been examined in great detail in this report. Parents, young people and service providers have all given us examples of where the system has failed, and failed dismally. The committee has come up with 129 recommendations for the government to consider. I would like to highlight some of these recommendations and speak briefly to them. At the outset I would like to say that we are facing two problems: firstly, the problem of dealing with the current crop of homeless young people, and, secondly and to my mind a far

speaker: Mr Quick (Franklin) (10.14 A.m.)
theText: I am delighted to be able to speak on A report on Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2051 more important issue, the way in which we must cut off the supply of potential homeless young people by instituting a range of effective programs across state and federal departments to provide support for families and their children. In our report we cover the whole spectrum of homelessness: the historical development of youth income support,the current services for homeless young people and the current income support arrangements for this group. I do not wish to tackle that in my speech here today. I would like to focus on some of the other aspects of the report. I see these areas as the key to really addressing this vital issue. These areas are: the housing needs of homeless young people; family mediation and counselling services; youth and family policy initiatives; Commonwealth-state responsibilities for the care, support and protection of young people; the role of education; and parental roles and responsibilities. Firstly, I would like to mention the issue offamily mediation and counselling services. This is an area in need of vast improvement across Australia, and more so in the rural and regional areas of our country. It really concerns me that our society still has not come to grips with the realisation of the importance of these valuable services and the need for them to be integrated into all aspects of the life of a family. Like most community services which operate in our country, they are poorly equipped to deal with their case load, are underresourced with staff, usually situated away from their client base, and are the subjeCt of disputation between various state and Commonwealth government departments. It is interesting to note the comments of the Institute of Family Studies concerning an evaluation of the 11 pilot projects for family mediation set up by the Commonwealth government recently: The study supports the view that early intervention in situations of family conflict may prevent seemingly ordinary problems from escalating into crisis situations and leaving home with little or no support. The Attorney-General's Department's comments are also of interest: The preventative nature of the adolescent mediation and family therapy program means that it is more successful at reaching those clients who have not already left home. The target population is therefore potentially greater than the number of clients currently receiving homeless rates. Clients attending services are still at home and school and are experiencing difficulties which may eventually result in homelessness. What is the use of setting up excellent services if they are hamstrung, unable to cope with their case load, and raise expectations within the community only to let these people down through no fault of their own? Nationally we have an expectation that, irrespective of where we live in this great country of ours, we can equitably access telecommunications, postal and educational services. When it comes to health and community services, it is a real lottery. It all depends on where people live. Our recommendations 7.19 and 7.20 are vital if we as a country are ever to develop an effective and responsive network to support all families. Recommendation 7.19 reads: The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth and State and Territory governments immediately establish funding arrangements for the extension of Adolescent and Family Therapy and Mediation Services in a national program as a preventive measure for young people leaving home prematurely. Recommendation 7.20 reads: . . . recommends that targets be established for ensuring the establishment of adequate coverage of mediation and family therapy services in all States and Territories within the next three years. MC 2052 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 It is imperative that, as well as doing this, we establish an effective linkage between other services offered and operated by the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Attorney-General's Department, the Family Court, and state education, housing and community services departments. At present, there is no such linkage, no effective network, no safety net. There is enormous duplication and an ineffective response to this vital issue. In the area of Commonwealth-state responsibilities for the care, support and protection of young people, it was interesting to read the initial knee-jerk response by all s.tates and territories to the release of our report, and more especially to the nine recommendations in this section of the report. Put the states under pressure and they trot out all the defensive cliches to try to deflect any blame. States are hopelessly blinkered into a departmental territoriality syndrome. When it comes to young people, examples of interagency cooperation are a rarity. All states have youth affairs departments, and they are almost exclusively located in the premiers' offices. They are all token efforts, having no effective liaising role, no resources, no clout when it comes to decision making. State and territory governments are responsible for child welfare but, because of Commonwealth involvement in a number of programs for families and their children, the states have sought to relinquish their responsibilities under the claim of fiscal incapacity. Services offered by state governments have been pared to the bone in the name of fiscal restraint and responsibility. Staff in these areas are inadequately trained and resourced and families in need have been extremely disadvantaged. It is interesting to note the comments in the 1989 Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report in this area which concluded: The failure of State welfare and health authorities both to provide appropriate and timely assistance to families in need and to prcivide appropriate nurture and support to children committed to, and leaving, their care, is a serious indictment on the willingness and capacity of those authorities to properly discharge their legal and social responsibilities ... The States are ill-equipped or unwilling to offer appropriate services ... Nothing, I would venture, has changed since this damning statement six years ago. We have now been offered the magic word 'protocol'. A federal-state government case management protocol for young people has been agreed to and signed by all parties. It acknowledges a shared responsibility for the welfare of children. It sounds fine in theory, but in practice out there in the real world it is a hopeless mess. It has been operating for close on a year. Our committee members were told of the following concerns in relation to the effectiveness and implementation of this protocol: the inability of state governments adequately to respond to the demands of the protocol in major cities as well as in regional areas of Australia; an increased worKload generated by the protocol placing an unmanageable burden on a service already unable to meet its statutory responsibilities to young people; young people becoming further disadvantaged as a result of the cumbersome bureaucratic procedures in operation; the inadequacy of state and territory welfare departments' financial support during the risk assessment period and beyond; the lack of accountability of the states and territories for the actions taken following referral; and, lastly, the failure of the protocol to include access to education. The area of parental roles and responsibilities is the area of our report which .produced the most angst from the members of the public who made submissions to us and from members of our committee. Of course it is controversial. When state and federal government policies Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2053 and programs impact on family relationships and arrangements, of course you will upset some people in our society. The most contentious issues are access to income support and the extent to which it acts as an incentive to young people to leave home, and the supremacy of children's rights over the rights of parents. It is interesting to note that there is consensus between parent groups and community and welfare organisations on a range of other issues dealing with young people. These are: the lack of preventative and early intervention services for families and adolescents; the inadequate support offered to families by state welfare authorities; the lack of responsibility and accountability of both the Commonwealth and the state governments for the welfare of young people receiving the homeless rate of income support; the need to improve and increase the training and the skills of people working in the youth field; and the absence of adequate and accessible family support services for families and adolescents. These issues and the other issues mentioned today are not barrows which the committee members are pushing for their own political advantage. Unless the Commonwealth and the state and territory ministers responsible for these areas bite the bullet and seriously look at the recommendations contained in our report and work tirelessly to implement them, we will end up with a situation which is evident in many other areas of the world where youth is out of control and where the services are inadequate. The punitive measures which are being forced upon these governments are far more costly and far more divisive than anything that we could ever envisage in this country. All members of the committee worked tirelessly to produce this report, and I thank them. It is a bipartisan report with a few exceptions towards the end. I can understand the concerns of members opposite, but we can work together to implement the many recommendations in this report. I trust and hope that the families who put submissions in, the service providers who are working tirelessly for young people and the Commonwealth and state government agencies who have the responsibility to ensure that these programs work effectively will examine the recommendations so that we can come to a sensible and effective conclusion in resolving this matter. speaker: Mr Richard Evans (Cowan) (10.30 A.m)
theText: I wish to talk about the report of the HouseMC 2054 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 significant report and one to which a lot of members should address themselves, if they have a caring position for the community. The fact is that we have a serious problem with some of our youth, although not with all of our youth, because most of our youth are quite well regarded and take their positions. in the community. But we do have a serious problem with some of our youth in Australia at the moment. The facts speak loudly. The number receiving the youth homeless allowance has risen from 950 recipients to almost 10,000 in recent times. There are estimates that approximately 40,000 young people are considered homeless. This report investigated these issues and it is quite significant in some of the issues that it discusses and in its recommendations. It does not really try to seek solutions. Rather, it allows for further discussion on the whole matter of youth homelessness. It is a very important issue and is something that we, as parliamentarians, should be considering very urgently because, in my view, we have an urgent problem. Young people have a right to a future and to have some hope in our country, and it is a major problem for a country as rich as Australia to have young people, without much hope and without much future, seeking some respite from their own family home through no fault of their own. We should be nurturing our young people, who are really the major asset of our country. We should be trying to look after them and provide a future for them. Yet we have an estimate that some 40,000 young Australians are considered homeless. I do not think it is because of poor parenting, although I believe that a lot of parenting skills are not inherent: they have to be developed and taught. Perhaps we should be considering the teaching of parenting to classes in the community. It is not that we are trying to protect these young people by institution ali sing them. I do not think We should be doing that either. We should be trying to protect them, giving them some opportunity for the future, some choices that they can be making to provide a future for them. The report discusses a lot of recommendations. However, there are a couple of things that I should comment on. One is the role of the states. In my view, in most states that we visited, not enough attention is being paid to our youth in this particular area. The particular area of 15to 16-year-olds is a very grey area of responsibility at the federal level, and at the state level it is very grey indeed. A lot of these people who consider themselves homeless fall into this particular age group. I also strongly suggest that we look at early intervention measures. A case recently which related to community services in New South Wales is a typical example. Unfortunately. a young child, six years of age, was beaten by his parents and died. Two weeks prior to this event, the mother contacted community services and asked for help and gave them an early warning signal, but no-one took appropriate action and we lost a young child. In this report we have identified a number of people who asked for early intervention, for some help, and the help was not available. It really is a tragedy, when families in Australia are asking for help to be able to overcome some problems they have within the family, that we are not responding quickly enough. I ask the state governments to review the whole process of how they respond to these issues. In Melbourne, I was impressed by a parent who gave some evidence; I think she was from the Geelong area. She spoke of three types of children who are homeless. One type was the child that is abused-physically, sexually, emotionally or mentally. The second group includes the children who do not know what is going on. To use her description, they have 'storms in their head'. They are going through a difficult period of growing and they are not necessarily Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2055 overcoming some of the challenges facing them. Of course, the third group is those that fraudulently take advantage of the system. The trouble with youth homelessness, I believe, is the perception in the community; and perceptions are reality as it is seen. The perception is that most homeless youth are troubled, they are taking advantage of the system, and they should go home to their parents. I have been to a public meeting and listened to parents quite dramatically and emotionally express their feelings towards government department officers. A lot of parents out there would like to have their children back. But the problem is deeper than people taking advantage of the system. There are children who are abused, and we should be responding to that. There are young people who do have problems with their families. They may perceive problems with their parents,while the parents do not perceive any problems with their children. Some do have these storms in their heads, and some are children who are defrauding the system. This report has a problem in dealing with those three separate areas. It is very difficult to differentiate between them; and when we consider youth homelessness as an issue, too often we try to put all three groups into one bracket. It cannot be done: we have to address them as separate issues. Frankly, this particular report does not have any solutions to that, but it again reinforces the point that this whole issue needs further investigation. As I said before, I went to a public meeting at which parents were really grieving for their children. They could not understand why their children did not want to live at home, and they could not understand why state departments were not giving information to the parents. One parent explained her situation. She and her family went along to a squat to see her 14-year-old daughter. She had been away from home for about 12 months, and in that 12 months had been raped by some of the squatters in the same place, but she was choosing to live away from home. The mother explained the story quite emotionally, saying how the child's father was on his knees pleading with her to come home. These parents have no solution themselves, but they are grieving. I wonder whether we should be providing some sort of counselling to parents. We talk about mediation, we talk about counselling, and we talk about reconciliation and bringing these people together. But if they· are not· reconciled, and they will never be reconciled, there do not seem to be any counselling services available to parents-services they can actually go to and express their grief. It would be like having a death in the family to lose one of your children-a child you love and cherish; To not have the child with you any more would be like having a death in the family, and there is no counselling to assist that grieving process to take place. At this public meeting, the parents were really emotionally grieving, but there was not any help for them. So not only do we have to consider the future of the children in these particular instances; we should also be considering the parents and the families they leave behind. We have a minority report. Most of my colleagues on this side of the House have supported the report in most of its recommendations, but there are a couple of areas that we have concerns about, and we have expressed those concerns. One is the administration of the whole process, and the other is the abuse claims. There does not seem to be any recommendation within the report about an appeal process for parents in relation to abuse. What we are suggesting is that perhaps that should be available to parents. At the moment, if a child does claim abuse, there does not seem to be any follow-up by any of the state bodies, including the police. I think any abuse should be investigated, because of other siblings who might be MC 2056 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 involved; but there is no appeal process at the moment for parents to have their day in court, and to discredit any other claims of abuse against them. So we need to look at that. The report is a significant report. We ask for its consideration by the government. We ask for the government to respond to a number of recommendations and I hope that it does that quickly. I have had other experiences in this place and on a number of other committees. I have been waiting for some response by the government for over two years on one very important report that I am dealing with concerning another committee. I am asking the government to respond to this particular report quickly because it is a significant report. I hope it is not lost through the election debate that is going on at the moment. If we have an early election, I hope that this report does get responded to in this particular parliament. I think it should because it is quite significant. My colleagues have mentioned the staff of the secretariat and the way they have handled the whole process of this inquiry. They have been very good at it. They have provided a lot of the information. I would also like to acknowledge my colleagues on both sides of parliament. I think they have been very compassionate in their dealings with this particular issue. It was something that was important for each of the people on the inquiry. It has shown that we as human beings are quite compassionate; we do not necessarily bring politics into our thinking all the time. I think that was shown during this whole inquiry. I would like to commend my colleagues on their attitude to the entire inquiry. Finally, I think this is an important issue. It is something that is not going to die. Youth homelessness is a growing problem in the community. It is something we need to address quickly in order to seek some solutions. I ask the government to respond to this report and I ask the state governments to treat it with some sort of urgency as well. youth homelessness inquiry. A report on aspects of youth homelessness is a good report because it finally lays to rest the myth that the existence of income support encourages young people to run away. I speak from absolute knowledge that young people are not, and have never been, encouraged to run away. For 10 years I worked in a family group home in Launceston and worked with many young people who could not and should not ever have had to live at home under some of the circumstances they were in. Therefore, the youth homeless allowance is of great assistance to many of our young Australians who often are in desperate and dire need of some support. Recently, I noted that it was very good of Senator Jocelyn Newman to write to the Launceston Examiner and alert the people of Tasmania to possible fraudulent claims on the Commonwealth for youth homeless allowance applications. As honourable members know, the allowance is administered by the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. One does wonder, however, about the motive of Jocelyn Newman. After all, there is possible fraud going on all over the place where a benefit can be obtained. There are possible fraudulent claims on many public and private institutions. Fraud is a fairly serious business. To make allegations in a newspaper about a possible case of fraud by an unnamed young person is certainly not something to be treated lightly. According to the senator's letter in the 31 May edition of the Launceston Examiner, a conspiracy of teenagers is at work here. speaker: Mrs Silvia Smith
theText: Tasmania's Austudy youth homeless rate recipients resident in theMC 2058 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 There is a lot of work involved in this issue. It is very sensitive and public servants also know that, with every grant or rejection of the independent rate based on extreme family circumstances, someone' s nose is going to be put out of joint. What showed up through the report and the undertakings throughout the country was that, in general, everyone who was involved was bipartisan. It is rather a shame that certain people easily whip up something that is very sensitive into a greater issue withouttaking into account the fact that we need to look at it carefully to make sure that all our young Australians, who desperately need our guidance and assistance through allowances or subsidies, are looked after. The case that I mentioned that was cited by Senator Newman represented the classic low act. I do not think anyone who publicises the fact that they are representing a particular person in need does that individual a favour. No rort was shown to have occurred. When the committee invited submissions, because Senator Newman actually felt so concerned about it, we would have hoped that she would have raised those concerns with the committee, but unfortunately she was not able to be in attendance at any of the hearings. We had a very good hearing in Hobart where some 11 individuals or organisations turned up and told us in no uncertain terms of the situation in Tasmania. I was advised that Senator Newman's letter in the Launceston Examiner appeared only a matter of a few days after she wrote to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training( Mr Free), so there had not been enough time for a reply. As a member of the committee looking into youth homelessness, I found it rather disturbing that a single case in the northern part of Tasmania, in my electorate, had been publicly discussed and had not been brought to our committee for discussion. I and no doubt every other member of the House would agree that Austudy should not be made available to students who simply are not getting on with their parents, or to students who are rorting the system, or to students who are fraudulently claiming circumstances which might qualify them for Austudy. I hope that every member would also condemn the way in which any other member would use this issue to promote suspicion and distrust of the way that student assistance is being administered. That is there to help the young homeless people to continue their lives and to help them continue their education. From past experience in working with those people for 10 years, I know that they have often found themselves in appalling and disgusting circumstances at that stage of their life. This is a good report. It recognises the sensitivity of these situations. It places a great deal of emphasis on case review, which itself will go a long way to foster reconciliation where possible. Most importantly, this report calls on the states to play their roles and to accept their responsibilities on these issues. The Commonwealth is essentially the financing agent for the program and is not equipped to play the enforcement role. The Commonwealth-state liaison must be addressed to achieve increased efficiency in delivery of the system. The report also deals with children under 16 being referred to refuges as step one rather than receiving the benefit. These are sound and well thought out recommendations to deal with a very difficult and a very sensitive problem. This report represents a pro-active approach, unlike writing to a local newspaper in an endeavour to score some cheap political points. BeforeI close, I would also like to pass my thanks to the chairman of the committee, the member for Newcastle ( Mr Allan Morris), who is present, and to all my fellow committee members. A special thanks also must go to Bjame Nordin, Peta Fitzgibbon, Lynette Sebo and Jodie Williams from the secretariat for their hard work, assistance and guidance. It was Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2059 certainly much appreciated. I would also like to publicly thank the 19 individuals and 130-plus organisations, 11 of those from Tasmania, who took the time to offer their submissions to the committee. I would like to say that their thoughts, their ideas and their suggestions throughout those hearings were much appreciated. I commend the report to the House. on Community Affairs on aspects of youth homelessness has in fact been tabled in the House and I have spoken on it in the chamber. This morning I just wish to add a few comments to the remarks that I had made that day. As we know, times for consideration of reports are short and this report is in fact very long. The report contains 129 recommendations. I touched on some of those in my earlier remarks, and I would like to go to a few more of them now. The first one I want to touch on is the fact that many people in submissions raised the question of some form of temporary payment for young people who are homeless or being evicted or being left stranded in traumatic circumstances and then it taking a substantial time for them to find some form of support. That is certainly a serious issue that we should be aware of. But at the same time there was a concern that that may well lead to frauding or to the allowance and support being diminished or demeaned in the minds of the community. We therefore recommended that the applicants should be dealt with very quickly. In other words, if the government could not respond within a day or a day and a half or so of an application, that was the government's fault and not the applicant's fault, remembering that in the report we recommend that all such applicants should have face to face assessment by a professional social worker and that it not be done by telephone or some other form of correspondence. I will come back to that in a moment. We have recommended therefore a probationary period for the allowance, so that within six weeks of the first payment being given the department would be required to review whether that payment should be sustained, and the review would be required to be substantiated with a case plan. I am not wishing to use the words 'case management' there but 'case plan' to make sure that we have taken into account the person's circumstances: home life, relationship with families, schooling and accommodation. So rather than simply granting an allowance and leaving it at that we recognise that the money is not usually the major problem; it is very often the other aspect, the support, that a young person needs. The first six weeks is the best possible chance for reconciliation with families. In that context the other raft of support measures such as extended families comes into play. A young person being fostered by a stranger is giving more support to that family than if it is some relation. In other words, we may well be able to find in that first six weeks, in that probationary period, alternative arrangements that offer more than money but rather offer support for that young person. That probationary period is a fundamental shift in concept because it indicates to the young person and to the family that the payment is not a permanent process but rather a means towards establishing a better long-term circumstance. That long-term circumstance may well be independent living or it may be reconciliation. There is a range of choices. The way that it has operated to date has been very black and white: if a person receives a payment, someone is making a permanent judgment about him or her and/or the family, and that is not helpful. Going further in terms of the alternatives available, the honourable member for Bass( Mrs Silvia Smith) spoke just briefly about refuges. The fact is that as a government, with the agreement of state governments, we do not allow special refuges for young people under the age of 16 years. We accept that they can go to a youth refuge as a matter of crisis or a matter of urgency, but we do not accept that refuges are solely for under-16-year-olds.

speaker: Mr Allan Morris (Newcastle)
theText: by leave-This report from the Standing CommitteeMC 2060 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 That really does pose a major problem. What we are facing around Australia is effectively a lack of alternative care. We were told by state departments that adolescents of 13, 14 or 15 years age who may have had behavioural problems, who may have had problems at school, who may have had problems with family breakdowns, are hard to foster. In addition, with the reduction in the number of state institutions-and institutional care is not the appropriate form anyhow-we are finding a very big gap in community support. Refuges are not a good place for young people to go to. The age group for youth refuges is notionally 12 to 14 years of age, so we may have a 13-year-old or 14-year-old who has just left home under extremely traumatic circumstances in a crisis situation housed on a temporary basis with young offenders, people in their early 20s in very difficult circumstances. In the same way as gaols are not necessarily a good place to send people for relatively minor offences, the refuge situation is not advisable. That point of view came through from the whole community. Refuge workers were telling us that they should not be taking in 16-year-olds and 14-year-olds and 13-year-olds because it is not an appropriate environment. So we have suggested that the state and Commonwealth governments should explore an alternative form of SAAP which focuses on younger people. Some form of community living, where people can live in a community context but with a home style environment, is required. Some states have played with the idea of community housing but, quite frankly, we could not find enough examples to justify using them as a model. They were too discrete and too narrow, if you like, for us to say that they would be suitable across the country. At the same time as we had the Commonwealth and states saying that they would not have SAAP accommodation solely for under-16-year-olds, which is an acceptance of the fact that it is not appropriate, we had the refuge in Western Australia that I mentioned where five of the six young people staying there were under 16. In other words, five-sixths of them were under 16. The reality is that an enormous number of young people are going into refuges because they have nowhere else. There is a desperate need for SAAP to be refocused. The report strongly urges the state and Commonwealth governments to review that situation and to perhaps look at some SAAP accommodation services that would be for under 16-year-olds but different from what we have now. Another point that we need to perhaps emphasise more strongly is the question of psychiatric illness, its prevalence and how it is treated. The report quotes the evidence of Professor Kosky, who was an extremely valuable witness to the inquiry. He had a great d.eal to offer in this area. He pointed out that about half of all psychiatric illnesses are diagnosed by the age of 19 and that the median age for half of those diagnosed mental disorders is 16 years. The under-20 age group receives about seven per cent of the funding. Adults make the decisions about the budget but it is that youriger age group where there is an enormously high level of psychiatric disorders. The budget that goes towards that group is in fact is very low and quite disparate. At the same time, with the deinstitutionalisation of psychiatric institutions that has been occurring; we are finding fewer and fewer resources available. The capacity for youth workers to diagnose whether a person has a behavioural problem or a psychiatric problem is minimal. There is no training available. These youth workers are not trained in that way. In fact, in the Northern Territory, we found that there are no psychiatrists, so people could not be diagnosed. There is a failure by governments, state and federal, to recognise that psychiatric illness is a Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2061 major issue with young people. The illness is both undiagnosed and untreated. It is certainly that group which provides the major source of homelessness. Professor Kosky also made the very valid point-I do not think anybody else raised it-that, in many cases, a young person with a psychiatric problem, which may be developing even before they reach their teens, will be seen as having a behavioural problem. Because the illness happens gradually and develops over time, the family will accommodate it and it often leads to a family breakdown. So, rather than the homelessness being a result of family breakdown, the family breakdown may be a result of a psychiatric illness that is not diagnosed. The parents, the family and teachers see it as a behavioural problem. They see the child as being wayward, undisciplined, uncontrollable, all of those terms that we use. In fact, Professor Kosky pointed out that in many families one parent will often take the side of the child and the other parent will not. It is that difference which often breaks up the family itself. Undiagnosed psychiatric illness of some young Australians is leading to family breakdown, which, in turn, leads to homelessness. Lack of perception and understanding of that is a major problem. This whole area is ignored. So when we talk about training our youth workers we are not talking simply about training in counselling. We are talking about training in recognising that a young person may not have a behavioural problem but may have a psychiatric problem which, if treated and dealt with, may mean that person can be restored not just to the community but to his or her family. A division having being called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 11.07 a.m. to 11.21 a.m. available. The first one is the question of schools as a place for early intervention and early recognition of a young person-and, in many cases, a family-experiencing trauma. It has been raised with me that teachers are trained to teach people, and that is certainly the case; but teachers are also very aware when their students are in difficulty or their performance changes dramatically over a short time. The fact is that in most cases they have no-one that they can refer to, because our systems are so caught up with crises. What we need to see is a much closer partnership between the education system and the community services sector-and, in some cases, the health sector-so that when a teacher perceives that a pupil is in difficulty there can be a very quick response at that very early stage. The way to address this problem is to try to prevent it occurring in the first place. Homelessness is not always preventable, but it certainly can be diminished from what it is now. That would require intervention and family support much earlier than we currently have it. One of the vehicles that we propose in the report is the use of the auditing provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. That is being put forward as a vehicle for premiers and prime ministers to start to look at policies on children and the family as one policy-across, between and within governments. Within anyone government we may have five or six ministers and departments all covering this area. In the states we have health, education and community services and juvenile justice departments all involved in some way. When looking at state and federal ministers combined, we may have 30 or 40 ministers involved, and their areas are treated as separate issues. We are arguing that there should be one policy within each government-one policy for each state government and one policy for

This report is tabled by the committee, but it belongs to a lot of people. All those people who took part in the inquiry are now part of the result of it, and I encourage them to stay in support of this issue. Debate (on motion by Mr Hicks) adjourned. Employment, Education and Training Committee Report Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Fitzgibbon That the House take note of the paper Employment, Education and Training for this particular inquiry, but I am interested in training programs in Australia, particularly in the vocational education sector of Australia. It is for that reason that I took an interest in the report entitled A best kept secret. That is an excellent title for this report, because training schemes in Australia do not have a high profile with the general public, but they do very effective work within the community and their role is very important. The reference was to look into improving small and medium sized enterprises' participation in, and access to, the training market, including Australian vocational certificate training, and training services that could be offered. It is very important that we are aware of how we can actually improve small and medium sized business enterprises in their training. The big companies in Australia are able to do this because they have the resources, the personnel and the financial facilities. But the small and medium sized businesses do need expertise and they do need skills in their particular businesses. Australia does have to work out how best to ensure that our young people-and sometimes riot so young people-are given the opportunities to upgrade their skills. This issue is particularly to the fore at the moment in Tasmania. I know of a couple of medium sized engineering companies and one of them feels that it may even have to relocate to somewhere else in the world because it cannot get the skills from the work force that is presently there. That problem is in relation to building the big catamarans in Tasmania. The demand for building more of these large vessels has created a demand for skilled people. But
