speaker: Mr Miles (Braddon) (11.25 A.m.)
theText: I was not a member of the Standing Committee on Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2063 within Tasmania and, the company thinks, within Australia there are not sufficient people skilled to undertake these projects. That is a concern for a country like ours. The group training schemes in Australia are very well placed in that regard because they enable small and medium sized businesses to take on apprentices or trainees-which are the two areas the schemes cover-and, if a particular business has a downturn, the person can be slotted into another enterprise but their training or apprenticeship can be continued. Once upon a time, the situation was that an apprenticeship was indentured to a particular company or person and if that person's business went through very difficult times and the apprentice or trainee had to be put off, they were left in limbo. Quite often that happened to many of our young people. So the group training schemes, which have actually been around since about 1981, came into being so that we could try to create a situation for training our young people without them running into the possibility that the business they had gone into was unable to see them right through to the end of their training or apprenticeship. The group training scheme is an excellent way of meeting the ups and downs of industry, of small business and medium sized businesses, but at the same time ensuring that we have a mechanism for training skilled people. This report really does underpin and give new impetus to group training schemes and I am pleased to be able to make a few comments about it. It is very important that we have this sort of structure in Australia so that, as we go through adjustments in the economy, there is flexibility to maintain a training base at the apprenticeship and traineeship level. The second issue discussed in this report is that of links with schools. At this stage, there are not good links with the schools in regard to training. I believe that within Australia there needs to be a restructuring in regard to our schooling and training, and in how ANTA operates TAFE colleges. This raises the question of the division of our schooling system into primary, secondary and college sectors. This is a historical division and I do not believe that it is any longer appropriate for our schools. The report alludes to one of the difficulties in regard to training: the lack of contact in Australia between training mechanisms and schooling. If we looked at this area more thoroughly, we would find that the division in educational terms probably should come at the end of year 8, instead of at the end of year 6. We need a new grouping, a new way in which we operate our schools, such as a segment from year 9 to year 12, or even from year 12 to year 13. Perhaps there should be educational institutions which run from year 9 to year 15, with diploma courses. There needs to be a linkage with training now, particularly from year 9 to year 12. Many of our young people who are going on to apprenticeships or vocational education are in schools in year 11 and year 12. They do not want to go on to university, but they do want to start to develop their skills in a particular vocational area of interest, long before year 13. This report does give some indication of a greater need for linkages for some of our students. I believe that those linkages should run, in particular, from year 9 to year 12. There is a great need. Those schools which are involved at these stages say that there is a lack of the support and funding required to bring about this adjustment. On the one hand, there is ANTA, which funds the technical and further education colleges and training institutions around Australia, but on the other hand there is a lack of interface with the schooling sector. This report alludes to that deficiency in its overview and recommendations, when it says: MC 2064 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 The development of links between schools and work places is a key component to the success of the Australian Vocational Training System. I would like to underscore that. There is a need now for the articulation of linkages between our schools and the training system. The third point I wish to raise is that the committee noted: ... there are grounds to question the value of short non-accredited and non-articulated vocational training courses which were developed without extensive input from prospective employers. There are large numbers of our population, mainly young people, who are in training programs which are non-accredited and non-articulated. Frankly, most labour market programs of that type lead nowhere. We are deluding many of the people who go into these training courses. They know that it is tough out there to get jobs and they believe that those courses will lead to reasonable possibilities of employment. In fact, there are probably hundreds of people who are already more qualified in those particular vocations than those who do the non-accredited and non-articulated vocational training courses. This report highlights once again the lack of reality there is in our spending, as a nation, a lot of money on courses which lead many of our young people nowhere. I think many of us know that out there in these labour market training schemes there are people who have done course after course and are becoming pretty disillusioned because the courses mean nothing. They mean nothing to employers, in particular. Ultimately, the people who have done them see them as irrelevant and worthless. WhatI would encourage the government to ensure is that all training courses are in some way accredited and lead on to further courses. A labour market training program or course, even if it is for only 10 weeks, should in some way be articulated to and linked in with either a certificate course or a diploma course. It should not be a dead-end training scheme. I believe we are, essentially, only conning people who get involved in these training schemes. What they really need to be given is courses which are accredited. If we are going to have a successful Australian vocational certificate scheme, all our resources involved in training need to be directed into the types of courses which do have a genuine standing in the community, and particularly with employers. This report highlights the need, when we are talking about training in a whole range of industry sectors, to know where industry is going. There has been a problem with training in Australia, in that the people doing the training have often lagged behind in knowledge of where business is headed. I think that is one of the reasons why there is a lack of skilled people in certain sectors within Australia. In that sense we need to move particularly to a much more market orientated training system, as I believe is the present view of the board which runsANTA. The group training schemes in Australia are involved with 14,000 or so people at the moment. About 13,000 of those are apprentices and about 1,200 are trainees. They fulfil a vital role in the training sector within Australia. To ensure that they continue to do that I would support the recommendations in this report that there is a need for core funding to these organisations to be maintained so that they can plan and know that they are secure. They are a flexible arrangement which ensures that training and apprenticeships can be ongoing, irrespective of the downturn of particular businesses, so that people can be moved around. That is vital. There are always going to be adjustments in the Australian economy, across a whole range of different vocational areas. Group training schemes, as this report states, are ideally suited to ensuring that we have a trained work force. Therefore, I commend the report. Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2065 Employment, Education and Training and someone who took part in the development and finalisation of this report, I would like to start off by thanking the other members of the committee for the work that was done. A range of members put quite a bit of time into this report and I think the results are there in the recommendations and in the report itself. I would like to thank the secretariat of the committee, John Cummins and Lorraine Ball in particular, for the many hours of work that they put into the construction and development of this report. The work that they have done has been a significant consideration in coming forth with a report which is very extensive and comprehensive and gives a coherent approach toward what may happen in the future with group training-which, as the report says, is Australia's best kept secret. I will say a little bit on group training. As has been mentioned by the honourable member for Braddon( Mr Miles), it is a uniquely Australian system. We were unable to find evidence elsewhere in the world of a similar system. It has the capacity, when working correctly, to work into industries at all levels and particularly to develop training programs which are appropriate for small and medium sized businesses. As of June 1994 there were 104 group training companies across Australia and they employed approximately 13,000 apprentices and 1,200 trainees. The companies operate on an industry or a regional basis in both rural and metropolitan Australia and across a range of industries. It is interesting to note that, although apprenticeship numbers across Australia during the 1990s fell by 22 per cent, during the same period group training apprentict<ships increased by 28 per cent. In a situation where the market share was falling, the group training system was obviously doing something right in terms of its share of the market increasing. Industry group training companies operate in a range of sectors, for example, the automotive, retail, housing construction, electrical engineering, plumbing, finance, manufacturing, hospitality and local government sectors. The group training company acts as a broker and an administrator in the operation of apprenticeships. Many businesses are not large enough financially to sustain an apprentice in their own right and the administrative and other costs which relate to developing an apprentice are difficulties for small businesses. Often there are situations where particular industries are facing downturns. The circumstances this year may be such that a construction firm can afford an apprentice but the circumstances next year may be such that the firm cannot afford an apprentice. These circumstances create a number of problems for the apprentice. Occasionally an apprentice is midway through an apprenticeship and he or she loses the apprenticeship because of a downturn in the employing industry or company. This situation results in a loss to the nation in terms of the investment of education and training in the apprentice. The investment can be jeopardised or lost because of downturns in particular industries. Downturns in industry affect not only the personal situations of the apprentices involved but also the trained work force and the investment that Australia makes in its young people. Group training companies are able to rotate apprentices to industries where work is available. The committee was informed of occasions in the construction industry where, for a period of time, it may be necessary for the group training company itself to take apprentices on board in order to keep their heads financially above water until the industry improves and until opportunities are available for the apprentices to continue their training. In some circumstances, rotation results in a better rounded apprentice and, eventually, tradesperson; a tradesperson
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Griffin (Corinella) (11.39 A.m.)
theText: As a member of the Standing Committee onMC 2066 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 who is able, on occasion; to move from employer to employer, and, therefore, to become more aware of different aspects of their industry. The committee held hearings on the Gold Coast in Queensland and members of the committee were able to speak with people from the construction industry. An example was provided to the committee that an apprentice who works with one carpenter may become an expert at hanging doors or an expert in other aspects of the construction industry. In the process, that apprentice will obtain a broad understanding of a range of other issues. The apprentice will develop significant expertise in particular areas, but not in other areas. Through the group training approach, it is possible, on occasion, for apprentices to move from tradespeople who are working in particular aspects of an endeavour to tradespeople who are working in other aspects. Tradespeople are better tradespeople at the end of the process. They are better able to make their living and they are better able to contribute to the economic well-being of the country. There is another important issue about group training. Group training companies perform a pastoral care role in respect of their apprentices and trainees. The young people who go into apprenticeships are usually only just out of school. This employment may be their first paid employment and there can be a range of teething problems during their adjustment from school to empJoyment. Staff are available to assist with any problems that may occur in group training. Hopefully, they would be able to address problems which may develop in a young person's life which may jeopardise their capacity to continue with their apprenticeship and, in that way, improve the circumstances for a successful completion of that training and for transition to employment from education. With respect to the overall situation, training, diversity and independence are hallmarks of the group training companies. In that way they are able to adapt to circumstances better than in a number of other training programs. They are able to react to the needs of an industry and to the needs of a region much more quickly than many other forms of enterprise and ensure that they maximise employment and opportunity for the people they serve. One thing that came out through the inquiry is a concern that there is a lack of knowledge of the real importance that group training plays. Hence the title of the report, A best kept secret. One concern the committee did note and has asked to be acted upon in its recommendations is the need to further develop the concept of group training and the publication of that throughout the community. There are something like 30,000 small businesses which presently access group training, but in the region of 10 times that number of employers in the small and medium sized businesses are not aware of it, or do not access it but certainly could if circumstances allowed. Therefore, there is a capacity for a lot more employment to be developed out of this process and for a lot more valued and experienced trades people to develop. That scope ought to be used. Group training essentially has a community based structure in terms of its committee of management and it works very closely with industry in its area. In that way it is able to develop good quality programs in the local area. Another thing that the committee looked at was the question of links between schools and workplaces. There needs to be more publication of the value and opportunities of group training within the education sector. In that situation we mean particularly secondary schools but, also, to an extent, technical and further education. It was apparent from the committee's Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2067 hearings that there were quite a few schools which were not availing themselves of the opportunities and, therefore, not highlighting those opportunities to the kids who were coming through their system. That is a shame because there is a lot more capacity for things to be done in this sector. The member for Braddon talked about labour market programs and effective pathways in training. That is an issue which government as a whole has recognised is a concern and has tried to address in recent years. Certainly the development of the AVTS is about that. It is about developing pathways and having a situation where training-whether it be through T AFE, secondary school or through labour market programs-is designed to lead to qualifications that are real, are of value and can assist people to move into employment. A range of the changes that government is implementing at the moment is all part of that and should ensure that the results sought come to fruition. Another issue which was mentioned was core funding for group training companies. This concern was raised with the committee because of the great variation in the balance sheets of group training companies. We had circumstances where some group training companies had very significant financial assets while others did not. One thing that also came through from the hearings and the evidence taken was that there was a great variation in the level of accounting standards applied at various group training companies. The government has recognised that it is important that core funding be maintained and that essentially, although group training companies in some cases have moved into other forms of labour market programs and training and development, and that that is something that should be encouraged, the focus should still be on apprenticeships, in particular, and traineeships, and that in those circumstances core funding is essential. It should be recognised that sometimes there are very important reasons for the variation in financial balances according to group training companies. For example, a group training company operating in the building industry-an industry which is renowned for its highs and lows---can, more than most other industries, be facing the situation of having a number of apprentices in difficulty and needing subsidisation over a period of time until they are able to get employment elsewhere. In those circumstances, that larger financial balance sheet is essential. The question of what companies do with those financial assets is also important. We saw numerous examples of group training companies endeavouring to be innovative and intelligent about the use of those financial assets and trying to maximise the bang for the buck. That also has to be looked at. However, there needs to be an improvement in financial standards within group training companies. There needs to be a lot more detail and commonality in terms of statistics gained from those group training companies. What we have here with group training companies is a very good initiative. It is an initiative that can be improved on. What it requires is more information as to the success that is out there and the capacity to be able to use-that information in a way which benefits group training companies in terms of their initiatives, and which also benefits their target groups. By their target groups, I mean both the apprentices, potential apprentices and trainees out there, and also the businesses which they play an important role in serving. The other aspect is the question of best practice. We saw great variations in what group training companies do and how they do it. On some occasions, as I mentioned earlier, the circumstances of a particular industry or, for that matter, a particular region may justify the MC 2068 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 difference in the results that are achieved. However, I certainly took the view-and I think other members of the committee did too-that there were best practice stories out there that needed to be highlighted and that needed to be passed on to other group training companies in the area. In that way, we could develop a better system. Another issue which I had some concerns about during the inquiry was the placement of group training companies throughout Australia. It was apparent to me that there were some group training companies which had areas which were too large for what they were actually endeavouring to do. In that way, there were gaps in the overall regional coverage of the system. There were also gaps in terms of areas where group training companies were not allocated. In those circumstances, when we are looking at the establishment of more group training companies-and that is certainly something that should be considered-we must be very conscious of those gaps, we must endeavour to identify them, and we must ensure that resoufcing is committed where it is really needed. I would like to finish where I started and once again thank the members of the committee, including the member opposite, the member for Hinkler( Mr Neville), who played an important role in the development of this report. I would also like to thank the chair, the member for Hunter( Mr Fitzgibbon), for his activity and energy during the process of the hearings and during the report deliberations. I would particularly like to thank John Cummins and Lorraine Ball and the other members of the secretariat for the very hard work they put into what is an important report for government to consider and to act upon in the future. When we look at maximising the bang for the buck from government in terms of labour market and other programs, this is the way to go. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired) Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled A best kept secret: report on the role and effectiveness of group training companies. As the report's title says, group training has been, up to now, our best kept secret, but with the tabling of this report it has now become an open secret. I think the whole system that we have looked at is indicative of the unique way that we do things in Australia. As the member for Corinella ( Mr Griffin) said, we cannot just rest on our laurels and let things happen willy-nilly. This is a good model and it needs to be refined so that it can go on to deliver further forms of training. In saying that it is indicative of the unique way we do things in Australia, that is not to say that group training schemes are out of the woods, so to speak, in terms of their long-term security, or that they have a perfect structure. It is a matter of continuing improvement. Equ.ally, it can be said that the organisation has a lot more to offer in structured training as a partner with government and as a conduit for delivering training to neglected areas of enterprise, such as small business. Further, its multi-disciplined approach across a wide range of enterprises and trade sectors gives the scheme the opportunity to set standards of world's best practice in the area of vocational training. It is a concentrated group with a national structure and, through it, the government can channel best practice methods into training. It can become a leader. Its structure is such that it can set these new standards and methods of deliyery not only in group training but also in refinements of that such as competency based training. I spoke briefly on this matter when the committee's report was tabled in the main chamber, and I welcome this opportunity to expand on my views in this debate. I should declare that
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (11.54 A.m.)
theText: I rise to speak on the report of the House ofWednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2069 this is a movement very close to my heart. I do not have a conflict of interest in this, but I suppose I do have a profound interest in it as I was a founding director of a group apprenticeship scheme in the infancy of the organisation. I have seen it grow from one employee and a handful of apprentices, in my own area, to a scheme of 180 apprentices in Bundaberg and 130 apprentices in Gladstone in 1995: ' During the height of the recession, the organisation had been on the brink of potential failure only to bounce back through singular effort on the part of the manager, staff and directors. I have seen how demoralising it is for a team of voluntary workers to be threatened with the withdrawal of state and federal core funding. This is a very important aspect and I would like to touch on it. I am glad that the report deals with this in some detail. I will mention one of the instances that occurred at that time. There was a group training scheme, which can remain nameless, which was receiving $180,000 from the state and federal government. At that time, the scheme, with about 150 employees, was returning $540,000 to income tax collections. So, if we take $180,000 from $540,000, the public purse, be it state or federal, was $360,000 in ftont. Some schemes at tl}at time were threatening to close. Had that scheme or a scheme in similar circumstances decided to close, the cost to government of the dole would have been $900,000. So, on the one hand, we would have had a profit to the public purse of $360,000; on the other hand, there would have been a loss of $900,000. The difference to government would have been $1.2 million. If this is multiplied by the 50 or 60 schemes that were around at the time or by the 104 schemes that are around today, one can see the extraordinary potential that group apprenticeship schemes have not only in creating jobs and delivering vocational training but also in assisting government in removing the curse of unemployment and removing young people with skills from the dole queue. Group training is delivering about 11 per cent of Australia's apprenticeships and, in my own state of Queensland, it is as high as 15% per cent. In my own area, the Wide Bay, Central Queensland part of Queensland, at times the figure has been as high as 30 per cent. It could be said that, in the general area of my electorate, at times, nearly one-third of all the structured vocational training has been delivered by this scheme. As the honourable member for Corinella mentioned, the committee visited my electorate and I was happy for it to inspect works at three places-Bargara, Bundaberg and Gladstone-and we saw excellent work being carried out by BACAS, the Bundaberg group apprenticeship scheme, and GAGAL, the Gladstone scheme. Both organisations have bid for and received substantial housing projects from the Department of Housing, Local Government and Planning in Queensland. That is very much to their credit and it is hoped that will continue. Most of the schemes across Australia rely very heavily on the building industry in one form or another. If this is not to continue or is to be cut back because of the rise in interest rates or-to introduce just a small political dimension to this-the 12 per cent on building materials, I hope it does not impact on these schemes. At Bargara, near Bundaberg, and at Wattle Grove, in Sydney's west, we saw another interesting dimension of this: the delivery of competency based training in progress on site. We saw another innovative thing here, where TAFE teachers were delivering their vocational training and skills training not on the TAFE campus but away from the colleges in on-site classrooms. You yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, saw that. It was a particularly interesting concept. We were not just talking about theory; we saw it in practice. MC 2070 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 We heard of apprentices who potentially could be through their courses in 21 months by that method. I am not suggesting that they will be through in that time-there is something to be said for keeping young people under proper supervision for a longer period-but competency based training is something that cannot be overlooked. Again group training, because of its disciplines and its structure, has the ability to deliver those new forms of training in the best manner. This suitability to handle major projects such as in the building industry is illustrated by the fact that 21 per cent of all group training apprentices were employed in the building industry, while in the allied field of electrical, a large proportion of which is household el.ectrical, it is as high as 13'h per cent. We can say, I suppose, that over a third of all apprentices in group schemes are in the building industry or allied fields. The motor vehicle trade, at 15 per cent, and food, at 12 per cent, provide the next level, and at the third level we come to things such as metals and hairdressing. I am pleased to note that the first recommendation of the committee, of which I was part, is that the Commonwealth, state and territory governments should agree to continue to fund core activities. Having been on the committee I find that there is a mood in some sections of the bureaucracy at present that we can throw some money at a problem, we can get a committee of willing volunteers together and they will run it for us, and when they have been doing it for a year or two we will slowly withdraw the government funding. Nothing could cause more damage to the group training scheme than that attitude. Those who work on one of these committees know what it is like to have to select staff, to go to meetings to supervise the setting up of the organisation, to arrange for the employment of apprentices, to carry out all the financial disciplines that are required in a big scheme turning over millions of dollars every year-'--all this being done at difficult times by voluntary workers. The last thing they want is the threat of the core funding being removed. They are prepared to provide the time, prepared to provide the energy and prepared to make sure that the statutory requirements of the Companies Code are met-that the staff are disciplined through the proper mechanisms, that competent staff are there, that submissions to government are made in an appropriate and professional manner and that all those other duties that company directors have are carried out. They should not then have someone tum around and say , 'Well, you know, we are thinking of reducing your funding.' One of the criticisms of the scheme, which was touched on by the honourable member for Corinella, is on the matter of financial standards. We were not saying in the report that anyone was conducting a shonky business-quite the contrary. But we were saying that there were no common financial denominators against which the schemes or some of their programs could be assessed and judged. I think group training schemes would be well served, in getting the best practice into that field of group training endeavour, by having some common denominators so that government can make an assessment of where group training can go in the future. I would like to add my own note of criticism to this idea of some in the bureaucracy that it is okay for the group training schemes to fund their activities from non-core profits but under no circumstances are they to use their core funding to run other schemes. There seems to me to be a lack of logic in that equation. Also it portrays the bureaucracy as saying that it is okay to fund core activities out of profits made from other government and private programs. Again, there is that lurking suggestion that core activities somehow in the future might be able to be Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2071 funded privately. The core activities in all these schemes should be corralled and identified, which they will be if these new financial standards are invoked, and governments, state and federal, should concentrate on that area. What the schemes do beyond that is on their own heads and they have to account for that in the normal fiduciary ways. There were three areas that I found particularly interesting in the recommendations, and I was pleased to participate in them. There is the recommendation that the Department of Employment, Education and Training, in consultation with Group Training· Australia, develop a network of placement coordinators. Now that is happening in some respects on an informal basis between schemes but it is critical to have a form of coordination to place people in jobs at the end. The schemes have a very good track record. Just before I came in today, I had a look at some evidence that was given to the committee. The credit union group training company of New South Wales, New South Wales business trainees and the Bankstown retail skills centres were guaranteeing that over 90 per cent of their apprentices and tt:ainees would get jobs. That is an amazing strike rate, and it is not a strike rate that is coming out of other government workplace programs. In South Australia, in the hospitality industry it was found that those young people coming out of the group training schemes had a better chance of employment and a higher rate of employment than other apprentices. Again, it shows that young people who go through these schemes are much sought after. One other point I make on that is that having placement coordinators is a better form of control than just having case managers. Another one that I found pleasing was that group training should move in providing services for small business-I think that has been long awaited. Also DEET should accredit group training schemes to be able to carry out other labour market programs, and ANTA should allow group training schemes to carry out assessments. After all, they are the leaders in the field, yet sometimes they have to bring in people from organisations of lesser expertise to help them. I congratulate my fellow members of the committee, I compliment John Cummins and his staff and, indeed, compliment Tom Quinn, the President of Group Training Australia, for his cooperation with the committee. apprentices and place those employees on a rotational basis with host employers for the duration of their indentures. Group training is uniquely an Australian scheme of providing people with skills necessary to make them productive members of the work force . .The companies occupy a particular niche in entry level employment and training in small and medium sized business in Australia. Taken together, group trairiing companies are the single largest employers of apprentices and trainees in Australia. This makes them potentially one of the most powerful forces for the implementation of change. Their strength is their diversity, and the independence given to them gives them an ability quickly to respond to the special needs of their business clients, their industries and the regions they serve. The contribution that group training companies can make in ensuring that workers develop the skills necessary to guarantee Australia's long-term prosperity into the next century has been recognised. Group training companies have responded to the challenge of a radically changing approach to vocational education and training. This is particularly so in Tasmania, where there are no longer the same opportunities to train with big companies, to go from a trainee all the way through to the ranks of the executive.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Adams (Lyons) (12.09 P.m.)
theText: Group training companies recruit and employMC 2072 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 June 1995 Nowadays employers want skills from the time the worker starts and cannot afford to take on several levels of trainees. They could perhaps take on a first year trainee, but could not at the same time carry a third year trainee, whereas another company may require the skill level of a third year trainee and therefore be able to take on one at that level from the group training company. It gives the opportunity for trainees to gain their skills in a more varied environment. For instance, in the hospitality industry a first year trainee might start in a city takeaway and spend a second year in a hospital, a third year in a suburban hotel and a fourth year in an international hotel. This gives a much greater scope for experience than ever in the past. There are still some opportunities for going through with one company but these are much fewer than they were in the past. The development of links between schools and workplaces is a key component of the success of the Australian vocational training scheme.· As yet, many of the school systems have not reached out to create genuine learning partnerships with employers. This report says that group training companies are ideally placed to provide the link between schools and the workplace, and they must be supported to enable them to playa key role in the implementation process. Tasmania boasts one of the early group training companies, which was established through the boil ding industry training board, partly as a result of the downturn in the building industry. Stan Joiner set upa group training scheme in 1984 and had a contract for 48 apprentices over four years. In actual fact, the company had 57 in the first 2Y2 years. In 1987, the third full year of operation, itturned over $1 million dollars and was employing around 63 apprentices, with up to 60 employers on its books. It was successful because there were many employers who could not carry apprentices for the full four years and this scheme allowed them to retain apprentices. Their businesses had a lot more flexibility because of the scheme. Now there are many schemes all over Australia. But Tasmanians have become more innovative at times, because we have fewer resources than most other states-as I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker. Necessity being the mother of invention is avery apt idea for us. Now, as things change, the group training schemes themselves have to become broader and take on the concepts of both apprentices and trainees. They need to meld them, develop modules to suit particular industries or businesses, and develop what is, after all, a chance for young people to get the proper training so they can apply for jobs that are available. The report has recognised that the maintenance of funding of core activities is essential. Although other business activities are useful, they must not be at the expense of apprenticeships and traineeships, building the core skill level for our country. It is strongly suggested that funding be recurrent, to take into account the special role that group training companies play in enhancing the skills of the Australian work force. Group training can assist small business and there is a recommendation that will encourage small businesses to take advantage of these schemes and also seek to have them promote the services that group training can provide. There are a lot of other positive recommendations that come from this report. The committee found that group training has helped to get a lot of people back to work, and it has proved very successful in Tasmania; but we are still only dealing with a very small percentage. The challenge now is to get more people to use the scheme, and it appears that medium and small businesses can be a growth area if it is made easier for them to have access. This may be Wednesday, 21 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2073 helped by making the processes simpler and much easier to understand. There are so many different programs and names, and letters spelling out even longer names, that it is hard for everybody to keep u-specially people in small and medium sized businesses, who do not have the same access and opportunity to pick up on government programs. There needs to be a strong selling point from group training companies in this area. They have to market themselves much better. They need to be very conscious of being out in the marketplace, gathering in these small businesses so that they can become a part of group training's overall process. There is ongoing funding to promote the concept of group training, and this may help the process become simpler in the longer term. I am pleased to see you, Mr Deputy Speaker Ftizgibbon, in the chair. As you said in your speech introducing this report earlier this year, group training companies have shown their potential to adapt to changing circumstances by diversifying their activities, and it is important that this be recognised and that this potential be used to its fullest. I am sure that we all agree with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on those comments. This scheme should be used to the fullest extent, continuing to train Australians to give us the skill level that we need to be in front of our competitors in the world. As we go into Asia we need to continue to keep that skill level high, from our technical trainees through our fitters and our electricians to our building companies. We need to keep the skills right through, now that opportunities are broadening out for vocational training, and give people broader opportunities. We need to build those pathways into the future from our education system--from high school right through to people receiving degrees, in the longer term-over a longer period of time than we ever have in the past. Talking to a number of overseas people at the global cities conference in Melbourne last year left me in no doubt that Australia leads the world in the way that we are developing training and employment opportunities. This report is a very important part of that. There is no doubt that we are on the edge and that this report must be considered as an important part of the ongoing debate on training and the direction in which we are going. I have a daughter involved in group training, and she seems to be achieving a very good result from her involvement; so from a personal point of view this has also touched me. I commend the report to the house. Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
